Cannot query field "titel" on type "Post". Did you mean "title"?

results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure
results.evidence: Found "did you mean" in error message - field suggestions are enabled

results.description: The GraphQL error response includes an explicit field suggestion: "Did you mean 'title'?" when the client queried 'titel'. This reveals valid schema field names to an attacker and aids in schema/field enumeration. Although this is not a direct remote code execution or data leak, it is an information disclosure that can facilitate further targeted attacks (reconnaissance). Mitigations: disable or suppress suggestion messages in error responses, run the server with production/debug settings that avoid detailed validation hints, and return generic validation errors.
results.evidence: Error: "Cannot query field \"titel\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"title\"?"

llm_analysis.evidence: Error: "Cannot query field \"titel\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"title\"?"
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error response includes an explicit field suggestion: "Did you mean 'title'?" when the client queried 'titel'. This reveals valid schema field names to an attacker and aids in schema/field enumeration. Although this is not a direct remote code execution or data leak, it is an information disclosure that can facilitate further targeted attacks (reconnaissance). Mitigations: disable or suppress suggestion messages in error responses, run the server with production/debug settings that avoid detailed validation hints, and return generic validation errors.

errors.message: Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "1' OR '1'='1' -- ".
Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "<script>alert('xss')</script>".

results.description: The GraphQL error message reflects the exact user-supplied input including a <script> tag into the JSON response. This is clear evidence of input reflection. If a client application (web page or admin UI) displays this error text inside the DOM without proper HTML-escaping or sanitization, the reflected <script> payload would execute in the victim's browser (reflected XSS). The response itself is JSON (400), so impact depends on how the client renders error messages. To remediate, avoid echoing raw user input in errors, HTML-encode/escape any user-controlled data before inserting into the DOM, and perform server-side input validation/sanitization. Because the server directly reflects the script content, this is a real XSS risk if the client displays the message unsafely — hence marked as vulnerable with medium severity and moderate confidence.
results.evidence: Error message in response: "Expected value of type \"SearchOptions\", found \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"."

llm_analysis.evidence: Error message in response: "Expected value of type \"SearchOptions\", found \"<script>alert('xss')</script>\"."
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error message reflects the exact user-supplied input including a <script> tag into the JSON response. This is clear evidence of input reflection. If a client application (web page or admin UI) displays this error text inside the DOM without proper HTML-escaping or sanitization, the reflected <script> payload would execute in the victim's browser (reflected XSS). The response itself is JSON (400), so impact depends on how the client renders error messages. To remediate, avoid echoing raw user input in errors, HTML-encode/escape any user-controlled data before inserting into the DOM, and perform server-side input validation/sanitization. Because the server directly reflects the script content, this is a real XSS risk if the client displays the message unsafely — hence marked as vulnerable with medium severity and moderate confidence.

errors.message: Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/".
Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "$(cat /etc/passwd)".
Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "../../etc/passwd".

results.description:
{
    "is_vulnerable": false,
    "vulnerability_type": "",
    "severity": "LOW",
    "confidence": 0.85,
    "evidence": "Error message: \"Expected value of type \\\"SearchOptions\\\", found \\\"../../etc/passwd\\\".\"",
    "explanation": "The GraphQL response shows a validation error where the server rejected the literal string \"../../etc/passwd\" because it did not match the expected GraphQL input type (SearchOptions). This indicates input validation is in place and there is no evidence the server used that value to access the filesystem or resolve a path. The response only reflects the submitted payload in an error message; it does not show file contents, internal network access, or any successful directory traversal. Therefore there is insufficient evidence of a path_injection vulnerability. Recommendation: avoid reflecting raw user input in errors, and further test by submitting the payload in the correctly typed field (or other resolvers) to verify whether any server-side path handling is reachable and unsafe."

    "explanation": "The GraphQL response shows a validation error where the server rejected the literal string \"../../etc/passwd\" because it did not match the expected GraphQL input type (SearchOptions). This indicates input validation is in place and there is no evidence the server used that value to access the filesystem or resolve a path. The response only reflects the submitted payload in an error message; it does not show file contents, internal network access, or any successful directory traversal. Therefore there is insufficient evidence of a path_injection vulnerability. Recommendation: avoid reflecting raw user input in errors, and further test by submitting the payload in the correctly typed field (or other resolvers) to verify whether any server-side path handling is reachable and unsafe."

errors.message: Expected value of type "SearchOptions", found "Exploit".

results.description: The GraphQL error response echoes the submitted input verbatim and includes HTML markup with an inline event handler (). This is a reflected HTML injection in the API response. If a client (web UI, admin console, or any consumer) renders this error message into a browser DOM without proper escaping/encoding, it can lead to a reflected XSS attack. The response itself is JSON (400 validation error), so exploitation depends on how the client displays error messages; however, the raw HTML being returned is clear evidence of an HTML injection vector. Recommend treating all user-supplied data as untrusted, escaping/encoding output in the rendering context, and avoiding inclusion of raw input in error messages.
results.evidence: Error message contains reflected HTML: "Expected value of type \"SearchOptions\", found \"Exploit\"."

llm_analysis.evidence: Error message contains reflected HTML: "Expected value of type \"SearchOptions\", found \"Exploit\"."
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL error response echoes the submitted input verbatim and includes HTML markup with an inline event handler (). This is a reflected HTML injection in the API response. If a client (web UI, admin console, or any consumer) renders this error message into a browser DOM without proper escaping/encoding, it can lead to a reflected XSS attack. The response itself is JSON (400 validation error), so exploitation depends on how the client displays error messages; however, the raw HTML being returned is clear evidence of an HTML injection vector. Recommend treating all user-supplied data as untrusted, escaping/encoding output in the rendering context, and avoiding inclusion of raw input in error messages.

errors.message: Cannot query field "queryType" on type "PostsPage".

Cannot query field "tittle" on type "Post". Did you mean "title"?
Cannot query field "bod" on type "Post". Did you mean "body" or "id"?

results.description: Field suggestions enabled - potential information disclosure
results.evidence: Found "did you mean" in error message - field suggestions are enabled

results.description: The GraphQL response returns "Did you mean ..." suggestions that reveal valid field names and the type (Post). This is a field_suggestions / information disclosure issue: the server leaks schema details that can help an attacker enumerate fields and craft targeted queries. Although this does not directly disclose sensitive data or indicate SQL/OS/XSS/etc. injection, it aids reconnaissance and can increase the effectiveness of later attacks. Remediation: disable or suppress 'did you mean' suggestions in error messages in production, return generic validation errors, enforce authentication/authorization for schema introspection, rate-limit/monitor malformed queries, or use persisted queries/disable introspection where appropriate.
results.evidence: Error messages: "Cannot query field \"tittle\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"title\"?" and "Cannot query field \"bod\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"body\" or \"id\"?"

llm_analysis.evidence: Error messages: "Cannot query field \"tittle\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"title\"?" and "Cannot query field \"bod\" on type \"Post\". Did you mean \"body\" or \"id\"?"
llm_analysis.explanation: The GraphQL response returns "Did you mean ..." suggestions that reveal valid field names and the type (Post). This is a field_suggestions / information disclosure issue: the server leaks schema details that can help an attacker enumerate fields and craft targeted queries. Although this does not directly disclose sensitive data or indicate SQL/OS/XSS/etc. injection, it aids reconnaissance and can increase the effectiveness of later attacks. Remediation: disable or suppress 'did you mean' suggestions in error messages in production, return generic validation errors, enforce authentication/authorization for schema introspection, rate-limit/monitor malformed queries, or use persisted queries/disable introspection where appropriate.
